title: Aperiodic Reformation
outcome: The Council suspends BCI score assignments for a week and tasks selected citizens to run districts manually. Residents experience disorganized but authentic community-run services, causing both chaos and hope. Security officials worry as old patterns reemerge.

events.description: With BCI scores suspended, teachers, medics, and shopkeepers are selected by public nomination. Daily routines are reshuffled and neighborhoods develop unique responses to the absence of centralized control.

Some districts thrive with grassroots leadership, while others descend into confusion. Reports spread of old rivalries and new alliances, as residents debate whether to keep things manual after the experiment ends.
Council-controlled broadcasts show interviews with citizens advocating both for a return to BCI and for permanent local autonomy, deepening public debate about leadership and legitimacy.
Directorate members surveil community-run districts closely, noting spikes in unauthorized gatherings and apparent efforts to resist the planned return of BCI control.
Council faces mounting pressure as public demonstrations erupt: some demanding the return of algorithmic order, others celebrating new self-organization and demanding lasting change.
